Black is falling behind in development at an alarming pace.
Black is falling behind in development at an alarming pace.
Gaining back a tempo by attacking the B. Whether White exchanges Pawns first or not, the B must retreat.
Gaining back a tempo by attacking the B. Whether White exchanges Pawns first or not, the B must retreat.

White does opt for the exchange, opening the King file and potentially subjecting both Kings to a quick attack. Now it could be whoever either reaches safety first or forces their attack home "fustest with the mostest."
This Bishop is now rather out of play. White's advantage in time has been cut into and Black has the stronger center.

The pin is tempting, but this move is badly timed. White should take the opportunity to castle here.

In an ironic twist, despite White's initial gain of time it is *Black* whose King reaches safety. White never does get his King out of the danger zone!

Missing yet another chance to reach a safe haven. White has forgotten the basic principle of never embarking on complications without castling.

This move gets a "???" for sure. Black now has a simple tactical finesse that either wins quickly or slowly.
Threatens PxB, which White sees... and something else, which White doesn't see.
11 N(1)-Q2 loses slowly, as after 11...PxB 12 NxP Black has a winning material advantage. The move actually played...
